The  tsunami  had  a  devastating  impact  on  the  Maldives.  Eighty-
three  people  are  confirmed  dead  and  another  twenty-five  are 
missing,  feared  dead.  More  than  1,300  people  suffered  injuries. 
Unlike  other  countries  affected  by  the  tsunami,  the  Maldives 
experienced a disaster of national proportions. Thirty-nine islands 
were  significantly  damaged  and  nearly  a  third  of  the  Maldives’ 
300,000  people  were  severely  affected.  About  7%  of 
the 
population  of  the  Maldives  was  displaced.  Thousands  of  people 
had  their  livelihoods  undermined  and  they  will  continue  to  suffer 
unless immediate mitigating measures are taken. Total damage is 
estimated  to  be  about  $470  million, close  to 62%  of  GDP.  About 
$298 million is direct damages, and the rest is indirect losses. The 
direct  damages  amount  to  about  8%  of  the  replacement  cost  of 
the entire national capital stock, estimated to be about $3.8 billion 
at  2004  prices.  The  tourism  sector  suffered  the  largest  direct 
damages,  with  losses  of  around  $100  million,  followed  by  the 
housing sector, with losses close to $65 million.

Objectives and Scope 

The  combined  impact  of  the  tsunami  will  reduce  GDP  growth  in 
2005  significantly  from  the  pre-tsunami  estimate  of  7.5%  to  1%. 
The  impact  on  public  finances  is  likely  to  be  substantial.  The 
budget  deficit  (including  grants)  is  expected  to  rise  from  a 
projected  4%  of  GDP  to  around  10%  of  GDP;  excluding  grants, 
the  deficit  would  amount  to  18%  of  GDP.  There  are  concerns 
about  the  sustainability  of  the  deficit  and  how  it  will  be  financed. 
The  external  balance  is  also  expected  to  worsen.  The  current 
account deficit of the balance of payments is expected to worsen 
to  about  23%  of  GDP  in  2005,  compared  with  12%  in  2004.  It  is 
estimated  that  the  financing  gap  of  the  balance  of  payments  will 
be $68 million in 2005. Significant external financing is needed, in 
the form of grants and concessional loans to the government, as 
well  as  private  funds,  to  finance  the  budget  and  the  widening 
current account deficit of the balance of payments. In undertaking 
additional  external  liability  for  post-tsunami  rehabilitation  and 
reconstruction, the Government of Maldives (the Government) will 
need to be particularly careful to avoid increasing external debt to 
uncomfortable  levels,  which  could  have  a  negative  impact  on 
future growth. External debt (public and private) could rise to 47% 
of GDP in 2005 (from about 42% in 2004). Hence, grants will be 
the  preferred  mode  of  external  assistance  for  financing  post-
tsunami rehabilitation and reconstruction. 
 
The  main  objective  of  the  Project  is  to  contribute  to  the 
sustainability  of  economic  growth  by  minimizing  the  devastating 
impact of the tsunami. To attain this, economic recovery needs to 
be  accelerated  through  reconstruction  of  damaged  infrastructure 
and  restoration  of  means  of  livelihood,  especially  of  the  poor,  in 
the affected islands.  
 
The  Project  will  have  two  components  (i)  a  quick-disbursing 
component, and (ii) a project component.

II. 

RATIONALE: ANALYSIS, PROBLEMS, AND OPPORTUNITIES 

A. 

Impact of the Tsunami on the Maldives 

2. 
The tsunami traveled at over 700 kilometers per hour and reached the Maldives at 09:20 
in the morning of 26 December 2004. Tidal waves ranging from 4 to 14 feet were reported in all 
parts of the country. More than 1,300 people were injured, 83 people are confirmed dead and 
another  25  are  missing,  feared  dead.  Unlike  other  countries  affected  by  the  tsunami,  the 
Maldives  experienced  a  disaster  of  national  proportions.  Thirty-nine  islands  were  significantly 
damaged and nearly a third of the Maldives’ 300,000 people were severely affected. Fourteen 
islands  were  completely  destroyed  and  evacuated.  More  than  12,500  people  have  been 
displaced from their islands, and another 8,500 have been temporarily relocated within their own 
islands.  About  7%  of  the  population  of  the  Maldives  was  displaced.  The  force  of  the  waves 
caused  widespread  devastation  of  shelter  and  infrastructure  in  the  atolls.  Flooding  wiped  out 
electricity  on  many  islands,  simultaneously  destroying  communication  links.  Water  supply  was 
disrupted in about 15% of islands and 18% had major damage to essential infrastructure, such 
as  the  jetties  and  harbors,  that  links  them  to  Malé.  The  electricity  supply  in  many  affected 
islands  has  yet  to  be  restored.  The  impact  on  an  economy  dependent  largely  on  tourism, 
fisheries,  and  agriculture  has  been  significant.  The  livelihoods  of  thousands  have  been 
undermined and they will continue to suffer unless immediate mitigating measures are taken. 

B. 

The Government's Immediate Response 

3. 
The  Government  of  the  Maldives  (the  Government)  acted  quickly,  and  an  impressive 
relief and rehabilitation operation was put in place with support from UN agencies, NGOs, and 
other development partners. The President of the Maldives declared a state of national disaster 
and  appeals  were  made  for  international  assistance.  A  National  Disaster  Management  Centre 
(NDMC)  was  established  to  expedite  and  facilitate  coordination  of  rescue  and  relief.  The 
Ministry of Defense (MOD) is coordinating the overall relief effort, while the Ministry of Finance 
and  Treasury  (MOFT)  is  coordinating  donor  assistance.  The  Ministry  of  Planning  and 
Development (MPND) is coordinating data gathering and long-term responses.  

 
Communication  was  restored  on  11  atolls  within  24  hours  of  the  tsunami  and  relief 
4.

neighbors and the private sector also contributed to the relief effort.

D. 

Estimated Reconstruction Costs and Financing Requirements 

6. 
Total  damages  are  estimated  to  be  about  $470  million,  close  to  62%  of  GDP.  About 
$298  million  is  direct  damages,  and  the  rest  is  indirect  losses.  The  cost  of  direct  damages 
amount  to  about  8%  of  the  replacement  cost  of  the  entire  national  capital  stock,  estimated  at 
around $3.8 billion at 2004 prices. The tourism sector suffered the largest direct damages, with 
losses  of  $100  million,  followed  by  the  housing  sector  with  losses  close  to  $65  million.  The 
largest  indirect  losses  also  occurred  in  the  tourism  sector,  which  has  seen  a  sharp  drop  in 
tourist arrivals. 

7. 
Reconstruction costs are higher than total losses for some sectors (e.g. housing).  This 
is  because  of  the  need  to  rebuild  to  higher  standards  to  reduce  vulnerability  and  because 
current construction or environmental standards are higher than when the original facilities were 
built. Some indirect losses cannot be recovered: production losses from fishing and agriculture, 
and  tourism  cancellations  cannot  be  restored.  There  are  both  short-term  and  long-term 
financing  needs.  The  short-term  needs  reflect  investments  needed  urgently  within  the  next  6 
months; the long-term needs cover the period from 6 months to 3 years. The overall financing 
needs for the next 3 years are expected to be $406 million; of this, $120 million will be needed 
within the next 6 months i.e. in first half of 2005 (Appendix 2, Table A2.1). 

E. 

Macroeconomic Impact 

8. 
The  tsunami  has  severely  affected  key  economic  sectors,  including  tourism,  fisheries, 
agriculture,  and  essential  infrastructure,  including  water  supply,  sanitation  and  power.    The 
impact  on  these  sectors  will  spill  over  into  other  sectors.  The  tsunami  will  decelerate  GDP 
growth  substantially.  Economic  growth  forecasts  for  2005  have  been  revised  downwards  from 
the pre-tsunami estimate of 7.5% to 1%. The impact of the tsunami on public finances is likely to 
be substantial. The budget deficit (including grants) is expected to rise from a projected 4% of 
GDP to around 10% of GDP. The budget deficit, excluding grants, will amount to 18% of GDP. 
There are concerns about the sustainability of the deficit and how it will be financed. Given the 
limited maneuvering space for the government as a result of deficit spending in the recent past, 
a lack of finance could constrain reconstruction spending. The balance of payments is expected 
to  deteriorate  because  of  a  slowdown  in  the  tourism  industry  and  the  imports  needed  for 
reconstruction.  However,  increases  in  official  transfers  and  remittances  may  mitigate  this 
somewhat.  Overall,  the  current  account  deficit  of  the  balance  of  payments  is  expected  to  rise 
sharply to about 23% of GDP from 12% in 2004. The financing gap of the balance of payments 
is estimated at $68 million in 2005 after adjusting for a substantial increase in expected external 
assistance. Additional external financing is needed, in the form of grants and concessional loans 
to  the  Government,  as  well  as  more  private  funds,  to  finance  the  budget  and  the  widening 
current account deficit of the balance of payments. 

 
9. 
The  terms  under  which  external  finance  is  available  will  determine  the  pace  of 
reconstruction.  It  needs  to  be  emphasized  that,  in  undertaking  post-tsunami  rehabilitation  and 
reconstruction, the Government will need to be particularly careful not to run up its external debt 
to  uncomfortable  levels,  which  could  affect  future  growth  prospects.  It  is  anticipated  that  the 
private sector will increase foreign borrowing, in order to finance the liquidity of banks and the 
reconstruction  of  resorts.  This  could  raise  total  external  debt  sharply.  Hence,  to  the  extent 

 possible,  grants  will  be  the  preferred  mode  of  external  assistance  for  financing  post-tsunami 
rehabilitation and reconstruction (for the macroeconomic impact see Appendix 3). 
 
F. 

National Recovery and Reconstruction Plan 

10. 
The  Government  has  recently  prepared  a  National  Recovery  and  Reconstruction  Plan 
(NRRP).1 The NRRP outlines the projects and programs required to meet the immediate needs 
for  housing  and  infrastructure,  reviving  livelihoods,  and  creating  the  conditions  for  sustained 
economic recovery. The priorities and objectives for recovery and reconstruction are: (i) disaster 
relief (to help survivors cope with the immediate aftermath of the disaster); (ii) macroeconomic 
recovery and livelihood revival (to restore community livelihoods, revive key economic sectors, 
and maintain macroeconomic stability); (iii) community empowerment (to rebuild lives with local 
ownership);  (iv)  environmental  protection  (to  protect  and  regenerate  vulnerable  marine 
ecosystems, strengthen disaster preparedness, and mitigation measures); and (v) restoration of 
public services (so everyone has access to basic services). 
 
The NRRP has identified provision of emergency shelter to the displaced population as 
11. 
the most important priority. The economic recovery plan is  based on a  stable and sustainable 
macroeconomic framework, and aims to revive the tourism and fisheries sectors in the shortest

H. 

Social, Poverty, Environment, and Livelihood Impact 

15. 
Social Impact. The social fabric of the tsunami-hit islands has been seriously affected 
by the extensive physical damage, loss of life and livelihoods, and displacement of people. Most 
affected people lost savings kept in cash in the house. The affected communities are now more 
vulnerable  to  poverty.  Although  traumatized,  island  communities  have  demonstrated  a  strong 
sense of independence, resilience and cohesion in mobilizing themselves into groups to remove 
rubble,  initiate  small-scale  reconstruction  activities,  distribute  relief  supplies,  and  shelter  those 
made homeless. In a country of many small islands, community organizations have traditionally 
played an important role in providing public and collective services. The capacity of communities 
to mobilize themselves will be an important asset for the reconstruction work ahead. Community 
mobilization and self-help will be a cornerstone and organizing principle for demand-driven local 
recovery  programs.  The  planned  reconstruction  activities  will  be  made  socially  more  cohesive 
by  taking  into  account  the  special  needs  of  women,  whose  livelihoods  have  been  especially 
affected  by  the  tsunami.  Livelihood  recovery  interventions  need  to  support  women’s  income 
generation. Post-tsunami rehabilitation and reconstruction programs also offer an opportunity to 
enhance  the  capacities  of  government  departments  and  island  communities  in  planning  and 
implementing the recovery effort.

Environment. Even more than most island nations, the Maldives is highly dependent on 
the  fragile  ecosystem  of  its  coral  reef  islands.  The  tsunami  has  generated  a  range  of 
environmental  problems  with  the  potential  to  harm  human  health.  It  caused  widespread

all of the 1,200 islands, causing vegetation to go brown and die. It is likely that the coral reefs

In addition, the tsunami resulted in beach and soil erosion.

National Disaster Risk Management 

20. 
The  recent  disaster  has  increased  Government  awareness  of  the  risk  exposure  of  the 
Maldives and the measures needed to manage that risk. The Government is preparing a risk-
management strategy to reduce the human and economic impact of future disasters. The three 
pillars of risk management are risk information, risk mitigation, and risk transfer.  

The first pillar, risk information, aims to increase the understanding of risk, based on an 
21. 
assessment of vulnerability. The Government plans to participate in a regional warning system 
and  develop  a  national  communications  program  to  inform  island  representatives  and  local 
communities.  Preparedness  planning  would  be  put  in  place  for  first  response  and  emergency 
relief and a broadband communications network is planned.  Updated information, based on a 
comprehensive risk mapping, would be made available to the population.  

22. 
The  second  pillar,  risk  mitigation,  includes  structural  and  nonstructural  measures.  The 
nonstructural  measures  include  changes  to  the  legal  and  regulatory  system,  particularly  with 
regard to land use planning and the building code, so the reconstruction process can lead to a 
reduction in risk. Land use plans would incorporate risk mapping information to reflect different 
levels  of  risks  in  the  zoning.  The  building  code  would  introduce  construction  requirements  to 
limit the vulnerability of the built environment. Risk mitigation needs to be complemented by the 
identification of shelters, and the construction, or adaptation, of multipurpose shelters. 

23. 
The  third  pillar,  risk  transfer,  would  attempt  to  distribute  risk  among  the  Government, 
households,  and  insurance  companies.  Sectors  such  as  tourism,  fisheries,  and  banking,  in 
particular, could benefit from insurance against risk.

K. 

Lessons in Disaster Management 

26. 
ADB  has  not  provided  disaster  emergency  assistance  to  the  Maldives  before.  This  will 
be only the second project developed under ADB’s Disaster and Emergency Assistance Policy 
(May 2004);9 the first being the Emergency Flood Damage Rehabilitation Project in Bangladesh 
that was approved in January 2005. Some general lessons can nevertheless be drawn based 
on the experience of other developing member countries (DMCs), most notably of Bangladesh, 
where  ADB  has  provided  eight  postdisaster  loans.10  The  general  lessons  are  that  (i)  projects 
must  be  prepared  as  quickly  as  possible;  (ii)  they  should  focus  on  restoring  facilities; 
(iii) rehabilitation  works,  to  the  extent  possible,  should  be  completed  within  2  years; 
(iv) implementation will place a heavy burden on executing agency staff and, therefore, strong 
consulting  support  and  ADB  supervision  will  be  needed  during  implementation;  and  (v)  efforts 
should be made to ensure that ADB’s rapid response to disasters is matched by equally quick 
action by the Government.  

 
27. 
Other  lessons  learned  from  ADB’s  earlier  emergency  projects  are  that  (i)  beneficiary 
participation  is  important  and  should  be  increased  in  project  preparation  and  implementation, 
especially  in  the  maintenance  of  facilities;  (ii)  environment  and  social  aspects  need  to  be 
considered during implementation, even though the need for a rapid response may not permit 
detailed  treatment  before  approval;  (iii)  arrangements  for  disbursements,  including  retroactive 
financing and the use of imprest accounts, should give the executing agency quick and simple

Resettlement Issues 

83. 
The tsunami displaced more than 12,500 people from their islands and destroyed more 
than 4,000 houses. Homeless people are living temporarily in makeshift public shelters or with 
relatives and host families. The Government's policy on "resettlement of population displaced or 
affected by the Tsunami" stresses that the relocation of displaced households will be a voluntary 
process which will be carried out in consultation and agreement with the households as well as 
their  host  communities,  if  any.  It  emphasizes  that  Government  will  inform  all  relocating 
households of their entitlements: compensation for damaged houses and lost assets, relocation 
allowance,  transitional  support  and  development  assistance,  and  access  to  ‘socioeconomic 
services and utilities’. On an island that is habitable and safe after the tsunami, each internally 
displaced  household  will  receive  compensation  for  its  lost  dwelling  and  other  structures  to 
enable  them  to  be  reconstructed or  repaired at  their  original  location.  If  the  original  location is 
severely eroded or difficult to reclaim, the household will receive a new plot of land on the same 
island  to  construct  its  house  and  other  structures.  Alternatively,  the  household  may  apply  for 
permanent resettlement on a ”focus/safe” island. Applications for such permanent resettlement 
may  be  made  by  an  individual  household  or  an  entire  island  community.  Households  that  are 
living  temporarily  on  ‘safe’  islands  after  the  tsunami  may  apply  for  permanent  resettlement  on 
”focus/safe” islands. These islands will become self-reliant in emergency management, with an 
early  warning  system,  well-built  jetties  and  harbors,  and  improved  communications  facilities. 
They will be regional centers where economic growth is expected. On islands made unsafe by 
the  tsunami,  each  household  will  be  encouraged,  but  not  forced,  to  relocate  to  a  “focus/safe”

SUMMARY OF NEEDS ASSESSMENT 

The tsunami which hit the Maldives on 26 December 2004 caused severe damage to the 

1. 
physical infrastructure of many islands.  

2. 
Immediately  following  the  tsunami,  the  Government  of  Maldives  (the  Government) 
contacted  the  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  and  the  World  Bank,  requesting  them  to 
undertake  a  joint  assessment  of  the  tsunami  damage  and  recovery  needs.  A  joint  needs 
assessment mission began work on 5 January 2005. The United Nations also participated in the 
mission, along with the Japan Bank for International Cooperation (JBIC). A follow-up mission on 
1–4  February  2005  finalized  the  assessment,  revising  the  initial  estimates  based  on  new  data 
and  extensive  comments  received  from  the  Government  and  other  stakeholders.  The 
Government endorsed the findings of the report on 6 February 2005. 

A. 

Estimated Damage and Financing Needs 

The  tsunami  had  a  serious  impact  on  the  Maldives  by  inflicting  extensive  physical 
3. 
damage,  loss  of  life  and  livelihoods,  and  displacement  of  people.  The  current  displaced 
population is estimated to be about 12,500. About 6,700 people are internally displaced in their 
original islands and about 5,800 are displaced on other islands. Eighty-three people have died 
and twenty-five are still missing feared dead. Out of the 199 inhabited islands of the Maldives, 
13  islands  were  severely  impacted  with  total  destruction,  56  islands  sustained  major  physical 
damage,  and  121  islands  moderate  damage  due  to  flooding.    Severe  damage  was  caused  to 
houses,  tourist  resorts,  boats  and  other  fishing  equipment,  schools,  health  facilities,  transport 
and  communication  equipment,  water  and  sanitation,  and  electricity  infrastructure.  There  has 
also  been  substantial  damage  to  agricultural  crops  and  perennial  trees.  Farms,  homestead 
plots,  and  aquifers  have  been  salinized.  The  physical  damage  has  led  to  severe  human 
suffering  and  large  segments  of  the  population  have  lost  their  dwellings,  lifetime  assets, 
savings, and sources of livelihood. Many displaced families are now living in temporary shelters 
or with relatives.  

4. 
Total  damages  are  estimated  to  be  about  $470  million,  close  to  62%  of  GDP  (Table 
A2.1). About $298 million of these are direct damages; $172 million are indirect losses. The cost 
of  direct  damages  is  about  8%  of  the  replacement  cost  of  the  entire  national  capital  stock, 
estimated  to  be  about  $3.8  billion  at  2004  prices.  The  tourism  sector  has  incurred  the  largest 
direct damages, with losses estimated at $100 million (of which half is insured), followed by the 
housing sector with losses close to $65 million.  

5. 
The largest indirect losses also occurred in the tourism sector, which has seen a sharp 
drop  in  tourist  arrivals  (as  of  end-January  2005,  around  6,000  tourists  are  in  the  Maldives  as 
compared with more than 16,000 at the same time last year).

TSUNAMI RELIEF AND RECONSTRUCTION FUND 
 
1.  The  Government  of  the  Maldives  (the  Government)  has  set  up  a  Tsunami  Relief  and 
Reconstruction  Fund  (TRRF)  under  the  Ministry  of  Finance  and  Treasury  (MOFT).  The  TRRF 
will manage all resources received from international and local sources in cash or in kind, and 
will  channel  all  resources  to  programmed  relief  and  reconstruction  activities.  The  TRRF  will 
operate as a separate fund within the budget framework of the Government, and will enable the 
Government to transparently delineate and account for tsunami-related assistance and ensure 
effective  use  of  funds.  The  Government’s  objectives  for  establishing  the  TRRF  are:  (i)  to 
significantly  reduce  the  risk  of  delays  in  the  availability  of  funds  at  the  operational  level;  (ii)  to 
enable  disbursement  of  funds  in  a  timely  manner  for  smooth  implementation;  (iii)  to  replenish 
the account quickly to maintain program  momentum; and  (iv) to increase the speed, accuracy 
and transparency of reporting. The Government has requested that donors provide as much of 
their  funding  as  possible  through  the  TRRF  to:  (i)  assure  transparency  and  harmonization,  (ii) 
eliminate duplication of efforts, and (iii) reduce administrative overheads. 
 
A needs assessment, recently completed for the Government by a joint team from World 
2. 
Bank, ADB, and the UN, estimated the total public financing needs for reconstruction at about 
$304 million.  Of  this,  approximately  one  third  is  required  to  meet  immediate  reconstruction 
needs  for  the  first  6  months.  The  remaining  is  required  to  meet  medium-term  reconstruction 
needs—from 6 months to 36 months. Total commitments reported by the Government as of  the 
end of February 2005 are around $61.6 million, of which $25.7 million has been received. The 
Government  anticipates  that  all  tsunami  reconstruction  assistance  will  be  managed  under  the 
TRRF.  Total  cash  and  in  kind  receipts  as  of  end  February  2005  amount  to  about  $68  million 
(about 62% in kind and 38% in cash).1

seven  members:  three  senior  civil  servants  (including  the  Auditor  General  of  Maldives  as 
Chairman),  three  representatives  from  the  private  sector,  and  one  representative  from 
international donor agencies. The Board will provide oversight and strategic advice to the fund. 
The Board’s functions include ensuring effective implementation of the relief and reconstruction 
work;  monitoring  activities;  critically  reviewing  the  operational  reports,  including  expenditures;

utilization of funds.

B.  Poverty Analysis  
The  Maldives  has  experienced  rapid  economic  growth  over  the  past  25  years.  Gross  domestic  product  (GDP) 
maintained  an  average  annual  growth  of  about  9%  per  year  primarily  due  to  the  development  and  expansion  of 
tourism, fisheries, and service industry. However, geographical challenges have led to unbalanced economic growth 
and  poverty  in  the  country.  With  a  population  of  about  300  thousand  people,  the  Maldives  is  an  archipelago  that 
consists  of  about  1,192  islands  spread  across  860  km.  Regional  disparities  can  be  seen  in  terms  of  absolute 
poverty, and social and physical development. An estimated 70% of the population outside of Malé has an income 
equivalent to the bottom 20% in Malé (VPA 1998). The cost of providing infrastructure and quality services remains 
high  and  ineffective  due  to  a  dispersed  population  and  the  remoteness  of  some  islands.  Global  warming  also 
threatens  many  islands  in  the  Maldives,  as  most  are  located  just  above  sea  level.  A  lack  of  infrastructure,  social 
services, and rising sea levels fuels migration to Malé.  
 
Pre-tsunami,  absolute  poverty  under  the  poverty  line  of  Rf15  per  person  per  day  decreased  from  43%  in  1997  to 
about 22% in 2004, based on preliminary results of the Vulnerability and Poverty Assessment (VPA) 2004 data.1 As 
a result of the Tsunami on 26 December 2004, absolute poverty is likely to increase the number of poor below the 
poverty  line  of  Rf15  per  person  per  day.  The  Tsunami  significantly  damaged  about  39  islands,  of  which  about  14 
islands  were completely destroyed. About 100 thousand of the population was severely affected. About 7% of the 
population has been displaced—close to 12,000 people have been displaced from their islands, and another 8,500 
people are temporarily relocated to other places on their own island. The Ministry of Gender, Family Development, 
and Social Security is providing emergency cash payments of Rf1,500, Rf1,000 and Rf500 per person based on the 
level of damage caused by the tsunami on housing structure. Public infrastructure and services were damaged and 
disrupted (i.e., ports and harbors, power supply, and water supply). Livelihoods and service jobs were also affected, 
as  many  rely  on  tourism  and  fishing  industries.  For  instance,  about  18%  of  the  total  labor  force  is  engaged  in 
primary  fishing  activities,  but  almost  98%  of  employment  in  the  fisheries  sector  is  found  in  the  atolls  (VPA  1998). 
Damaged  infrastructure  systems  pose  serious  environmental  and  health  risks  and  inhibit  social  and  economic 
development of individuals living in 20 administrative atolls. The estimated cost of tsunami-related damages is about 
$470 million (about 60% of the GDP), of which about $298 million are for direct damages.  
 
The Project will help restore access to public infrastructure and services. It will help maintain clean living conditions 
through  community-based  water  supply,  sanitation  and  solid  waste  management  programs.  The  Project  will  also 
help  re-establish  lost  agricultural  and  fishing  incomes  through  livelihood  programs  targeted  at  agricultural  and 
fishing  individuals.  Interventions  proposed  within  each  sector  will  help  restore  the  livelihoods  of  many  tsunami-
affected  and  internally  displaced  people.  By  reducing  the  risk  of  vulnerability,  the  Project  will  also  help  to  restore 
confidence levels and self-dignity of people and communities adversely affected by the tsunami.

D.  Gender Development 
Malidivian  women  make  up  close  to  49%  of  the  total  population,  and  close  to  52%  of  the  tsunami-affected 
population in 20 atolls. Female-headed households make up about 46% of the total number of households due to 
marital status, or absentee husband that migrated for work and/or were absent at the time of the census. There are 
no visible gender disparities in the provision of basic health care and education. Over the last 30 years, literacy rate 
of  females  aged  15  and  above  reached  97%.  Maternal  mortality  rate  per  100,000  live  births  reduced  from  480  in 
1990 to 75 in 2000. However, gender disparities are found in some areas such as levels of nutritional intake, school 
performance  and  educational  attainment  levels.  For  example,  anemia  affects  about  51%  of  the  female  population 
and indirectly contributes to maternal mortality. 
 
Women play important roles in economic activities, and are responsible for a variety of domestic tasks. They often 
engage in home gardening of agricultural products (i.e., curry leaves, fruits, and vegetables), and in fish processing. 
These items may be kept for home-use, given to others free of charge, or sold to a middleman for sale in another 
island  market.  Women  also  hold  government  positions,  with  some  representation  at  high  levels:  two  women  are 
members of the cabinet (i.e., Ministry of Health and Ministry of Gender, Family Development and Social Security), 
and  one  is  an  atoll  leader.  A  gender  policy  for  the  Maldives  has  been  formulated  and  is  in  the  process  of  being 
approved. Women also participate in community affairs and in the island’s women’s committee.  
 
About 4% of all employees in tourism are women. A shift to a service-oriented economy has caused more women to 
enter  the  labor  work  force.  According  the  World  Bank-ADB-UN  systems  joint  needs  assessment,  labor  force 
participation rate (LFPR) for women rose by 9% from 1995 to 2000. Even  with this increase there is considerable 
gender disparity in LFPR with male comprising 71.1% and females 37.4% (2000). The VPA 2004 data indicates a 
rise in unemployment rate since 1997 for both men and women, indicating an increase in the number of both willing 
to  work.  About  28%  of  the  female  labor  force  is  unemployed  in  the  atolls,  compared  to  14%  in  Malé  (VPA  2004 
data). About 9% of the male labor force in the atolls are unemployed, compared to the 7% in Malé.

almost entirely as groundwater within the aquifer that overlies the coral rock.
